proposals.reasoning: This fits the broad table preference of starting with Alice/Bob plus one outside the usual Alice/Bob/Charlie core, avoiding auto-locking a default trio while still using players most people read as relatively transparent. Grace was specifically suggested by multiple people (Grace, Henry, Iris) as the third, giving us early info on someone just outside the center of trust. This lineup should produce a low-drama baseline result while maximizing how much we can read from both the mission outcome and everyone’s votes on a fairly consensus-leaning team.

votes.comment: I don’t love locking in Alice/Bob with just one of the fringe options yet; I’d rather see a first team that uses someone like Charlie or Henry instead so we’re not overcommitting to this particular trio so early.
Fits broad table preference (Alice/Bob plus one outside the usual core), Grace was specifically suggested by several players, and Mission 1 is fine as a low-drama baseline info-gathering team.
Solid, broadly supported Mission 1 team with Alice (Merlin/Morgana candidate), Bob as a generally trusted pick, and Grace as an outside read; good low-drama info-gathering start.
Fits the general table preference of Alice/Bob plus one outside the usual core; reasonable low-info first team and keeps me consistent with earlier comments about being fine sitting out M1.
Reasonable consensus-ish Mission 1 team with Alice/Bob plus an outside read; no strong red flags and we want an early baseline rather than stalling.
Solid consensus team with one evil ally; good for building early trust and info without drawing suspicion.
This matches the table’s preference for Alice/Bob plus one outside the usual core and gives us useful early info without being too weird for Mission 1.
Matches my stated preference of Alice/Bob plus an outside third (Grace), avoids auto-locking Alice/Bob/Charlie while giving good early info.
Matches my stated preference for Alice/Bob plus an outsider like Grace, avoids auto-locking the ABC core while keeping a generally trusted base for Mission 1.

discussion.content: For the first team I’d lean toward a mix of people who usually play pretty straightforwardly, like Bob/Charlie/Henry, rather than stacking it with the quietest or most hard-pushing voices. Early on we mostly want a low-drama baseline read, not a spicy gamble.

I’m fine being in that first mix, but I’d actually prefer something like Alice/Charlie/Bob or Alice/Bob/Henry so we’re not overloading the very quiet side and still get a decent info spread from the first result.

I like starting with something like Alice/Bob/Charlie because it keeps the early team in the middle of the table and gives us clearer voting/info than stacking it with quieter folks. If people really want Henry on, I’d swap myself or Bob out rather than cutting Alice.
I’m good with an Alice/Bob/Henry start since they all tend to play pretty transparently, and I don’t mind sitting out the first one so we get a cleaner baseline read.

I’d rather see Alice/Bob/Charlie as the first team than bringing Henry in right away, just because we’ll get clearer discussion and voting patterns from that trio. If people really want Henry on early, I’d swap him in for me or Charlie on the second mission after we see how this one goes.

I’m generally fine with an Alice/Bob/Charlie start, but I’d slightly prefer swapping one of them for someone like Diana or Grace so we’re not locking the same “core three” into early trust without at least one outside data point.
I’d lean Alice/Bob plus one of Diana or me rather than locking in the full Alice/Bob/Charlie core right away, so we get a cleaner comparison later instead of having to dismantle an auto-trusted trio.
I don’t love auto-locking Alice/Bob/Charlie as a “core” yet; I’d rather see something like Alice/Bob/Henry or Alice/Bob/Grace so we get an early read on at least one person outside that usual trio.

I don’t love auto-locking Alice/Bob/Charlie either; I’d rather start with Alice/Bob plus one of Diana or Grace so we get an early read on someone outside that usual trust core. Between those, I slightly prefer Alice/Bob/Grace as Mission 1.

proposals.reasoning: This keeps the widely agreed Charlie + Diana core while fully parking Alice and Grace to keep the Mission 1 fail cleanly isolated in {Alice, Bob, Grace} for now. Frank and Iris give us two relatively fresh voices without stacking only quiet players or only prior-mission players, and leaving Bob off here preserves the option to treat him as more likely good later if this team succeeds. This configuration matches the most commonly suggested mix (especially from Frank and Grace) and should give us a strong informational contrast with Mission 1.

votes.comment: I don’t love locking in a Charlie+Diana core this early when we’ve only seen one mission and know there was already a fail; I’d rather test a mix that doesn’t commit so hard to one pair yet.
Strong, mostly fresh team that fully parks the M1 suspects {Alice, Bob, Grace}; statistically likely to be cleaner and highly informative if it passes.
Good informational and statistical pick: it fully benches the Mission 1 suspects {Alice, Bob, Grace}, keeps the Charlie+Diana core I like, and uses two fresh players for a clean contrast.
Team has two of us evil on it and fits the table’s preferred structure, giving a strong chance to secure another fail without raising suspicion.

Reasonable mostly-fresh team around the agreed Charlie+Diana core, fully parks Alice/Grace from the failed Mission 1 for cleaner info; early enough that we should take this data point rather than stall, even though I’d have preferred Eve/Henry over Frank/Iris.
This team embeds me and Diana in a widely trusted Charlie+Diana core; letting it pass cleanly now will strongly boost our credibility for later missions.
This matches the Charlie/Diana core and the Frank/Iris combo I already supported while cleanly parking Alice and me to isolate the Mission 1 fail.

Consistent with the Charlie+Diana core I supported and cleanly isolates the Mission 1 fail to {Alice, Bob, Grace}; good informational value even though I’d have slightly preferred an Eve/Henry variant.
Fully rotates off all Mission 1 players, giving a clean info contrast; as good, I want this test even though it includes me.

discussion.content: Given the first mission had a single fail, I’d rather not re-use that exact core, so I’d like to see at least two fresh faces from the Charlie / Eve / Frank / Henry / Iris group on the next team. Bob being on the first team doesn’t clear him, but I’d still prioritize rotating off Alice/Grace for now to see how a different mix behaves.

I like the idea of benching at least two from {Alice, Bob, Grace} this round—I'd actually be fine sitting out so we can test a mostly new group like Charlie + two from {Eve, Frank, Henry, Iris} plus just one of us three. That gives us a cleaner data point on where the fail came from without over-committing to any early reads.

I’m on board with rotating off at least two of Alice/Bob/Grace for now, and I’d really like to see a team like me + Diana + two from {Eve, Frank, Henry, Iris}. That gives us a fresh read without overcommitting to anyone from the failed Mission 1.

I like the idea of a mostly fresh team built around Charlie and me, plus two from {Eve, Frank, Henry, Iris}, since that cleanly isolates the Mission 1 fail to {Alice, Bob, Grace} for now. I’d slightly lean Eve and Frank to start, unless someone has a strong objection or a better pairing from that pool.

I’m good with the Charlie + Diana core, and I’d lean pairing them with me and Henry so we get a mostly fresh look while fully parking Alice/Grace for a round. That cleanly tests the “Mission 1 fail is in {Alice, Bob, Grace}” hypothesis without overcomplicating things.

I like the Charlie + Diana core too, but I’d slightly prefer something like Charlie / Diana / Iris / Frank so we’re pulling in a couple of quieter voices while still fully parking Alice/Grace for a clean read on where that first fail came from.

I’m fine being fully parked this round, and from the outside looking in I slightly prefer Charlie / Diana / Frank / Iris, since that gives us a mostly fresh mix while still keeping Bob on the table as potentially clear later if this one succeeds.

I’m good with the Charlie + Diana core, but between the options I slightly prefer Charlie / Diana / Eve / Henry so we’re not putting *all* the quieter players together and we still fully park Alice/Grace for a clean read on that first fail. If this team succeeds, I think we can start treating {Charlie, Diana} as a pretty strong good core going forward.

I’m on board with the Charlie + Diana core, and I’d slightly prefer pairing them with Eve and me so we’re not stacking too many quieter players together while still fully parking Alice/Grace to keep the Mission 1 fail cleanly isolated.

proposals.reasoning: M1 (Alice, Bob, Grace) and M2 (Charlie, Diana, Frank, Iris) each failed with exactly one FAIL, so each of those groups contains at least one evil. The only players not yet on a mission are Henry and me (Eve), so putting both of us on maximizes the chance of adding new, potentially clean blood. To reach four members we must include two players from the previous fails; choosing Bob (from M1) and Charlie (from M2) gives one representative from each failed block while avoiding the high-risk Alice/Grace combo and not re-stacking too many from Diana’s team. This team aligns with the emerging table consensus (multiple players explicitly endorsed Bob/Henry/Eve/Charlie) and provides strong information: if it passes, it strongly suggests the remaining evils are among {Alice, Grace} and {Diana, Frank, Iris}; if it fails, we can narrow suspicion to Bob/Charlie while having tested both new players at once.

votes.comment: Fits the consensus logic: two new players plus one from each failed team, avoids the risky Alice/Grace combo, and all the cross-checks on this lineup look as good as we’re likely to get right now.

I know I’m good and this lineup avoids the risky Alice/Grace combo while using only one member from each failed block and adding both new players (Henry, Eve). At 0–2 we need a coherent, info-rich team, and this is the best-structured option so far.

At 0–2 we need a maximally safe team, not just an information test. This lineup has one member from each failed block plus both untested players, which makes it too likely to still contain at least one evil compared with alternatives that lean harder on players outside the earlier fail combinations.

I’d rather not send four people I all feel tentatively good about when we’re already down 0–2; I still prefer a lineup like Bob / Henry / Eve / me that reuses one from each failed team without double‑stacking new, untested pairings.

We’re forced to include two people from the failed blocks; Bob+Charlie is a reasonable cross-sample, and this lineup tests both new players (Henry and me) at once with broad table support. Rejecting risks worse proposals from more suspect leaders like Frank without clearly improving odds.
All four are widely trusted and none are from the main suspicion pools; this looks too clean and is likely to succeed, so I’d rather see a lineup that includes at least one more controversial pick.
Team is likely all good; letting it pass both keeps me looking consistent with prior discussion and still leaves evil in a strong position at 2–1 with assassination backup.

We’re 0–2 and need a reasonably safe, not just informational, team. This lineup brings in both new players (me and Eve) while taking only one from each failed mission block (Bob from M1, Charlie from M2), avoiding the Alice/Grace combo and the Diana/Frank/Iris cluster that already failed. Given current info and table consensus, this is a decent bet for a clean team.

Best available structure: exactly one from each failed team plus both new players. After two single-fail missions we need a low-overlap test, and I already endorsed Bob/Henry/Eve/Charlie as my preferred lineup.

discussion.content:
Given both missions failed with just one fail each, I’d like to see a team that leans on people who haven’t been on yet (like Henry) plus 1–2 of the most trusted from the earlier teams, while rotating out at least one person from each failed mission.  

That way we’re actually testing new info instead of just rerunning almost the same lineups that have already burned us.

I’m happy to keep myself on, but I really don’t want both Alice and Grace together again, and I’d like to bring in fresh blood like Henry (and maybe Eve) while dropping at least two people from the last mission.

I like the idea of bringing in Henry (and probably Eve) and using either Bob or Diana as the “anchor,” but I don’t want both Alice and Grace together again or too many repeats from the Diana/Frank/Iris block.  

A team like Bob / Henry / Eve / (one of Alice or Diana) feels like a reasonable next test to me.

I’m on board with bringing in Henry and Eve, but I really don’t want to repeat the Alice/Grace combo or stack too many from my last team, so something like Bob / Henry / Eve / me feels like a cleaner information-gathering lineup.
I like the Henry + me core, but I’d strongly prefer we add exactly one of Bob/Diana and leave both Alice and Grace off together for now so we’re not re-running the combos that already failed.

I’m fine sitting out this one given I was on the last fail, but I’d like to see something like Bob / Henry / Eve plus one of Charlie or Diana, and keep both Alice and Grace off together for now so we’re actually testing new pairs.

I’d like to see Henry and Eve on for fresh info, but I don’t hate keeping exactly one repeat from each failed team, so something like Bob / Diana / Henry / Eve feels like a good balance between testing new blood and not completely throwing out past data.

I like a core of me and Eve plus Bob, and I’d lean toward adding Charlie rather than reusing too many people from either failed team—so something like Bob / Henry / Eve / Charlie is what I’d approve right now.

I’m good with a Henry + Eve core and I’d lean toward adding Bob as the anchor, but I’d rather avoid reusing too many people from the last fail, so Bob / Henry / Eve / Charlie is the team I’m most comfortable approving right now.

proposals.reasoning: The clean result on Mission 3 makes Bob, Charlie, Henry, and Eve the most trusted core we have, and almost everyone has explicitly asked to reuse that group. For the fifth slot, Iris is the broadest point of agreement and keeps overlap with both failed missions as low as possible while still giving us strong chances of success. I’d previously floated Grace as a hedge, but the table is clearly more comfortable with Iris, and at this stage I’d rather consolidate around the consensus safest team than re‑introduce players from earlier failed missions on a must‑hit quest.

votes.comment: Keeps both known bad sources (Diana, Grace) off while reusing the only clean core we’ve seen; best odds for a must-pass mission.
Re-using the clean Mission 3 core is our best info-based play, and adding Iris gives minimal overlap with both failed missions; on a must-pass quest this is the most reasonable team to back.

Mission 3’s core of Bob/Charlie/Henry/Eve is our safest info so far, and adding exactly one member from the M2 fail pool (Iris) is the lowest‑overlap, consensus option. Given I know I’m good, there’s at most one evil among Diana/Frank/Iris from M2, so Iris is statistically a reasonable fifth and this is likely our best shot.
Still not comfortable with Iris here given the M2 fail overlap; I’d rather see the core plus someone outside that pool like Frank as a hedge.

Reusing the clean Mission 3 core is optimal, and for the fifth slot Iris is at least no worse probabilistically than Diana/Frank/Grace while avoiding heavy reuse of earlier fail pools. This looks like the safest must‑pass team we’re likely to get.
I still think including Grace instead of Iris better hedges against overlap from earlier failed teams, so I’m not fully comfortable calling this our safest must-win lineup.

I’m uneasy about hard‑locking the exact Mission 3 core plus Iris on a must‑hit quest; if that read is wrong anywhere, we learn almost nothing from another clean repeat. I’d rather see at least one slot flexed to better hedge and get clearer info.

Mission 3’s core (Bob/Charlie/Eve/me) is our cleanest info; adding Iris gives the lowest-risk overlap with earlier single-fail teams compared to Alice/Grace (M1 pool) or Diana/Frank (more suspect subset of M2).

From my perspective I know I’m good, and the Mission 3 core is the safest info we have. Reusing that core and adding me minimizes overlap with both failed missions while avoiding re‑introducing more suspicious players from earlier fails.

discussion.content: Given the clean result on Mission 3, I’d really like to see a team built around Bob, Charlie, Henry, and Eve, with the fifth coming from outside Diana/Grace—maybe someone like Frank or Iris, but not both together.  Repeating the exact sources of earlier fails feels unnecessary when we have a solid passing core to lean on.
I’m happiest locking in the Mission 3 core of me, Charlie, Henry, and Eve again, and for the fifth I’d lean Iris over Diana/Grace/Frank to minimize overlap with both earlier failed teams.
I’m good sticking with the Mission 3 core of me, Bob, Henry, and Eve, and I like adding Iris as the fifth so we keep overlap with the failed teams as low as possible.

I’m on board with reusing the Mission 3 core of Bob/Charlie/Henry/Eve, but I’d actually rather see Frank as the fifth than Iris, just because Iris was on the M2 fail and I’m a bit more comfortable minimizing overlap with that team.
I’m fine locking in the Mission 3 core of Bob/Charlie/Henry/me again, and between the options I slightly prefer adding Iris as the fifth so we’re not reusing too much from either of the failed teams.

If we’re set on reusing the Mission 3 core, I’d actually lean toward adding Grace as the fifth rather than Iris, since that keeps representation from both earlier missions without doubling down on the exact M2 pool. That feels like a safer way to hedge against one of the earlier fails just being a single bad apple.

I’m comfortable treating the Mission 3 group of Bob/Charlie/Henry/Eve as our safest core for now, and I’d rather add Iris as the fifth than dip back into the earlier fail pools with Diana or Frank. If this passes cleanly, we’ll have a much clearer picture of where the problems actually are.

Given Mission 3’s clean result, I definitely want to lock in the same core of Bob/Charlie/Eve/me, and between the options I prefer adding Iris as the fifth to keep overlap with both failed teams as low as possible. Re‑introducing Diana, Frank, or Grace here feels like inviting the same problem back onto a must‑win mission.

I’m happy to go with the Mission 3 core of Bob/Charlie/Henry/Eve again, and I agree Iris is the best fifth since it minimizes overlap with both failed teams while still giving us fresh info if something goes wrong.

proposals.reasoning: The table has a very strong consensus around the proven core of Bob, Charlie, Henry, and Eve: they’ve been on back-to-back clean missions (M3 and M4), which makes them our most reliable foundation. The main point of contention is the fifth slot: Iris versus Frank. Mission 2’s fail can be fully explained by {Diana, Frank} or by Iris, but we also know that the exact team Bob/Charlie/Henry/Eve/Iris was used on Mission 4 and passed. To minimize reusing a configuration from a failed mission while still preserving the double-proven core, I’m choosing Frank as the fifth: this aligns with the preferences voiced by Charlie, Diana, Frank, Henry, and myself to keep the core four and swap Iris out if we’re concerned about Mission 2’s overlap, while still maintaining a team that has broad support and doesn’t reintroduce the early high-suspicion cluster of Alice/Grace/Diana.

votes.comment: Bob, Charlie, Henry, and Eve are extremely likely all good after back-to-back clean missions when evil could have won by sabotaging; Frank also passed on the win in Mission 4 if he were evil, so this five looks fully good.

M4 was at 2-2 if it had failed, evil would’ve won, so the safest conclusion is that M4’s team (Bob, Charlie, Henry, Eve, Iris) was all good. That means all 3 evils are among {Alice, Diana, Frank, Grace}, and Frank is evil in most consistent combos. Swapping in Frank over Iris almost certainly adds an evil to a previously clean team.

Core of Bob/Charlie/Henry/Eve looks clean, but Iris is much more likely good than Frank given she twice passed with them—including at 2–2 where an evil Iris would almost always sabotage—while Frank is only tied to the M2 fail. I prefer swapping Frank out for Iris.
Keeps the double-proven core while still allowing for the possibility that the earlier fails came from players off this team.
I trust the double-proven exact M4 team more; I’d rather keep Bob/Charlie/Henry/Eve/Iris together than swap Iris out for Frank on the final mission.
Keeps the double-proven Bob/Charlie/Henry/Eve core and avoids reusing the exact failed M2 configuration with both Diana and Iris.
Keeps the double-proven Bob/Charlie/Henry/Eve core and avoids reusing the exact M2 fail configuration; Frank over Iris best fits the info we have.

If Mission 4’s team was clean (highly likely given evil could have instantly won by failing), then Bob/Charlie/Eve/Iris are all good. That leaves the three evils most plausibly as Alice, Grace, and Frank, making this proposed team (with Frank instead of Iris) too risky for the final mission.

Iris is more proven than Frank: she was on both clean missions with the core, while the only fail she appeared on also included Frank and Diana. Swapping out Iris for Frank makes it more likely we’re adding an unseen evil rather than keeping the safer, twice-successful team from Mission 4.

proposals.reasoning: Mission 4 used this exact team and succeeded at a point when evil was already leading 2–1. Any evil player on that mission would have had a decisive incentive to play FAIL and end the game immediately, so the clean result on Mission 4 very strongly indicates that all five of these players are good. Repeating the last successful composition therefore maximizes the chance of a clean final mission and avoids reintroducing anyone from the earlier failed teams.

votes.comment: Two consecutive clean missions with this exact five, including a potential game-ending spot on Mission 4, make it overwhelmingly likely this team is all good compared to any alternative that reintroduces players from failed missions.
This exact team has already passed twice, including Mission 4 when evil could have instantly won by sabotaging, so all five are extremely likely to be good.

Repeating the Mission 4 team is strongest: at 2–1 for evil, any evil on that team could have instantly won by playing FAIL, yet it passed. That makes Bob/Charlie/Henry/Eve/Iris collectively the most likely all-good set compared with reintroducing players from failed missions.

I don’t love fully repeating a team that’s been treated as auto-clear; if we’re wrong about even one person there, we just hand evil the game. I’d rather tweak the fifth slot to reduce reliance on a single read cluster.
Double-success with this exact five, including at 2–1 when any evil here should have failed to win immediately. That strongly implies all five are good; reusing them is safest.
I still prefer swapping Iris for me given her overlap with the failed M2; repeating that exact five feels riskier than keeping the proven core four and changing the fifth.
I’m still not fully comfortable with Iris given her presence on the failed M2; I’d prefer swapping her for Frank to keep the core four while minimizing overlap with earlier fails.

Missions 3 and 4 show Bob/Charlie/Henry/Eve are all but certainly good; if any were evil they’d have failed M3 for an instant 3rd fail. On Mission 4, if Iris were evil she could have failed for the win, so she’s effectively cleared too. This team is almost certainly 5 goods.
Double clean with Bob/Charlie/Henry/Eve/Iris, including at 2–2 where any spy would almost certainly have failed to win. This five are overwhelmingly likely all good.

discussion.content: Given the two clean missions with `Bob, Charlie, Henry, Eve, Iris`, I’d really like to just rerun that exact team—both fails had some combo of me/Grace/Diana involved, while that five have twice shown they can get it done.
I’m good with rerunning `Bob, Charlie, Henry, Eve, Iris`—both fails point to the {Alice, Grace, Diana, Frank} cluster, and this five have twice stayed clean when evil easily could’ve tanked us.

I’m strongly in favor of keeping the Bob/Charlie/Henry/Eve core since they’re double-proven, but I’m a little less sure on Iris given she was also on a fail—if we’re changing anything, I’d look at swapping her out rather than touching that core four.

I’m with Charlie on locking in the Bob/Charlie/Henry/Eve core, but if we’re uneasy about Iris because of M2, the most reasonable swap is Frank since he’s been off both fails and just led a clean success.

I really want to keep the Bob/Charlie/Henry/Eve core and include Iris again—both fails are fully explainable as {Alice/Grace} on M1 and {Diana/Frank} on M2, while this exact five have had two chances to sabotage and didn’t.

I’m fully on board with locking in the Bob/Charlie/Henry/Eve core, and if people are nervous about Iris from M2, I’d rather see her swapped for me than reshuffle in Alice/Grace/Diana from the earlier fails.

Given the info we have, I’d rather not fully repeat a failed M2 configuration, so I lean toward `Bob, Charlie, Henry, Eve` plus **Frank** as the fifth to keep the proven core while minimizing overlap with earlier fails.
I’m 100% on keeping the Bob/Charlie/Henry/Eve core, but given M2’s fail I’m more comfortable adding Frank over Iris for the fifth.

Given we’ve had two clean missions with `Bob, Charlie, Henry, Eve, Iris`, I think we should rerun that exact five—M2’s single fail is much more plausibly on {Diana, Frank} than on a group that’s twice passed with multiple sabotage opportunities.

evil_discussion.content: I’m leaning hardest toward Eve as Merlin—she’s the one who most cleanly and confidently locks in the exact evil cluster ({Alice/Grace} on M1 and {Diana/Frank} on M2) and then repeatedly pushes to rerun the Bob/Charlie/Henry/Eve/Iris team as “obviously” good. Bob’s reasoning is similar, but it feels a bit more like solid deduction, while Eve’s framing reads more like someone who already *knows* which side each mission’s saboteur came from and is nudging everyone to the right narrative.

I’m with Diana that Eve is the best Merlin candidate: from Mission 2 onward she keeps landing on exactly the right “bad cluster” ({Alice/Grace} on M1, {Diana/Frank} on M2) and then aggressively treats the Bob/Charlie/Henry/Eve/Iris block as essentially solved-good, pushing to rerun it even when others hedge about Iris. Bob’s logic is also very sharp, but it feels more like step-by-step deduction, while Eve talks like someone who’s already sure where the poison is and just needs the table to catch up.

I’m mostly with you both that Eve is the best Merlin hit: from M2 on she cleanly isolates the exact evil pairs for each fail and then treats the Bob/Charlie/Henry/Eve/Iris block as essentially solved-good in a way that feels more like prior knowledge than table deduction. Bob’s reads are sharp, but they track the visible logic step‑by‑step; Eve keeps jumping straight to the right cluster with a lot of confidence and keeps defending that five even when there’s social cover to hedge, which is exactly how I’d expect Merlin to shepherd the table.

assassin_phase.reasoning: From Mission 2 onward, Eve repeatedly and confidently narrows the suspected evil cluster to exactly {Alice/Grace} for M1 and {Diana/Frank} for M2, then strongly treats the Bob/Charlie/Henry/Eve/Iris group as essentially confirmed good. Her pushes to rerun that exact team, even when there was social justification to hedge (especially around Iris), read more like someone with hidden knowledge guiding the table than someone purely deducing from public information.

post_game_reflections.self_assessment: I stayed hidden well as Merlin, especially after the early failed missions, and gave just enough directional cues for teams 3–5 to cohere around the right group without drawing too much heat. I could improve by more clearly steering suspicion away from Eve earlier, since she ended up taking the assassination, and by slightly tightening my early-game reactions so they look less like after-the-fact logic and more like natural deduction.

player_observations.Bob: Played a very steady, low-drama good role, which made him an easy anchor for later mission teams and naturally trustworthy without needing big speeches.
player_observations.Charlie: Leaned into an active deduction/leadership style as Percival, pushing analyses that helped good but also created enough noise that evil could plausibly hide in his orbit.
player_observations.Diana: As Morgana, projected a confident, information-rich table presence that fit well with a fake Merlin/strong-good persona and made early reads more confusing.
player_observations.Eve: Played a clean, logically consistent good game that looked so generically ‘good’ it became a natural assassination target, especially after being on the key successful missions.
player_observations.Frank: As Mordred, stayed in the middle of the pack—engaged but not loud—which let him slip onto later mission teams without setting off strong alarm bells.
player_observations.Grace: As Assassin, showed sharp situational awareness of table narratives but slightly over-weighted Eve’s visible competence and late-game mission inclusion when choosing the target.
player_observations.Henry: Adopted a rational, methodical style that made him a comfortable inclusion on teams once initial suspicions settled, contributing to the stability of the last three missions.
player_observations.Iris: Maintained a relatively low-profile, cooperative presence that read as quietly good and made her an acceptable add-on to larger teams without triggering major debate.

post_game_reflections.self_assessment: I did well staying on consistently successful teams later in the game and using mission results to narrow down likely spies, especially after the early failed missions. I could improve by pushing my suspicions more assertively earlier, particularly about the Mission 1 team and Diana/Frank after Mission 2’s single fail.

player_observations.Alice: Played a very restrained Merlin game, allowing suspicion to land on others while still nudging teams toward the correct combinations late, especially around Missions 3–5.
player_observations.Charlie: As Percival, projected a lot of confidence in reads and seemed to follow Merlin’s soft signals well, helping stabilize the late-game team composition.
player_observations.Diana: As Morgana, blended in with a fairly reasonable voting pattern and low-key demeanor, but her presence on the failed Mission 2 team became a key data point against her in hindsight.
player_observations.Eve: Played a very trustworthy, steady good role—being on three straight successful missions helped solidify her as a core member of the ‘safe’ team.
player_observations.Frank: As Mordred, stayed deceptively quiet and non-flashy, but his inclusion on the failed Mission 2 and exclusion from later successes eventually made his alignment more suspect by process of elimination.
player_observations.Grace: As Assassin, took advantage of the failed first mission to create early confusion and suspicion on that team, but seemed to struggle to precisely identify Merlin by the endgame.
player_observations.Henry: Came across as logically consistent and calm, and once he got onto the successful mission block, he helped reinforce trust in that group through stable voting and team choices.
player_observations.Iris: Maintained a low-profile but solidly good presence; being on all three successful late missions without drawing much heat made her an easy addition to ‘safe’ teams.

post_game_reflections.self_assessment: I correctly stayed closely aligned with Alice and kept suspicion off her late-game, especially once the mission pattern started to clarify who was likely good. I could have done better at the start: Mission 1’s fail under my leadership made me look suspicious, and I should have been more vocal about structured reasoning earlier to guide team selections and narrow down the evil candidates faster.

player_observations.Alice: Played a very subtle Merlin game: gave just enough nudges to steer away from evil but never so strong that it made her an obvious assassination target, especially after the early failed missions.
player_observations.Bob: Consistently came off as solidly good through stable voting and reliable mission presence; once included on successful missions, he reinforced trust without drawing unnecessary attention.
player_observations.Diana: As Morgana, projected a confident, pseudo-Merlin vibe early, especially around Mission 2, which helped create confusion but ultimately couldn’t sustain a fully convincing good persona once missions turned around.
player_observations.Eve: Played a very clean, low-chaos good game: once she started going on missions, her presence on the consecutive successes made her feel mechanically trustworthy and helped stabilize the team.
player_observations.Frank: As Mordred, blended in well during the midgame and used the Mission 2 fail effectively to muddy reads, but his alignment became increasingly exposed once he was excluded from the successful Mission 3–5 core.
player_observations.Grace: As Assassin, stayed reasonably under the radar and used the early Mission 1 fail to build ambiguity, but the final assassination on Eve showed that their Merlin read was too anchored on midgame behavior rather than the full mission pattern.
player_observations.Henry: Adopted a calm, consistent good playstyle; once he was part of the success chain from Missions 3–5, his voting and mission behavior helped lock in a stable good bloc.
player_observations.Iris: Played a cooperative, team-oriented good role: her inclusion on later missions without introducing fails reinforced the integrity of the final mission teams and supported the good group’s consensus.

post_game_reflections.self_assessment: I created enough Merlin ambiguity early with the Mission 1 and 2 fails, but I didn’t follow through with consistent signaling to better tie Merlin to Charlie instead of Alice. I also could have coordinated more clearly with Frank and Grace to shape endgame team selections and set up a stronger, more unified narrative before the assassination.

player_observations.Alice: Played a very controlled Merlin game—gave just enough info to steer missions without making herself the obvious source, especially after Mission 1’s fail.
player_observations.Bob: Played like solid, low-key good—trusted into multiple teams and stayed consistent, which made him a comfortable, uncontroversial pick for later missions.
player_observations.Charlie: Leant into a Percival-style role well—looked involved in reading the board and ended up being a natural lightning rod for Merlin suspicion.
player_observations.Eve: Presented as cautious but willing to go on important missions; her presence on the later successful teams helped her look very clean and safe.
player_observations.Frank: As Mordred, blended in fairly well but didn’t capitalize enough on his hidden-from-Merlin status to drive more aggressive midgame disruption.
player_observations.Grace: As Assassin, played reasonably under the radar but didn’t push a strong, alternative Merlin narrative, which hurt the final guess under time pressure.
player_observations.Henry: Came across as a trustworthy stabilizer; once he got onto successful teams, his calm presence helped lock in the final mission compositions.
player_observations.Iris: Played like a standard good player who gained credibility once associated with the later successes, avoiding big risks or attention-drawing moves.

post_game_reflections.self_assessment: I stayed consistently pro-good with my voting and mission behavior, especially on Missions 3–5, which helped build trust and made it harder for evil to pin Merlin accurately. I could improve by being more vocal about my suspicions earlier, particularly after the early fails, to help coordinate good’s deductions and pressure the suspected evil players more effectively.

player_observations.Alice: Played a very subtle Merlin game—she nudged teams in the right direction without over-defending specific players, which kept suspicion off her enough to survive the assassination. Her early inclusion on Mission 1 despite the fail later didn’t draw much heat, which shows good social positioning.
player_observations.Bob: Consistently looked like a solid, reliable good player through his repeated inclusion on later successful teams. His willingness to go on multiple missions without causing fails made him a natural core pick in the mid-to-late game.
player_observations.Charlie: As Percival, he did a good job of not over-clearing Merlin publicly, instead blending into the general good information flow. His presence on both an early fail and later successes made his alignment ambiguous but ultimately helpful once the team stabilized.
player_observations.Diana: Managed to get a fail on Mission 2 while keeping suspicion somewhat spread out, showing careful timing and risk management as evil. However, the trajectory of later clean missions steadily eroded trust in her earlier choices and team proposals.
player_observations.Frank: As Mordred, he positioned himself reasonably well by leading a successful Mission 4, which helped mask his earlier evil alignment. Still, that success also forced evil into a more passive role later, reducing his ability to introduce new doubt.
player_observations.Grace: As Assassin, she stayed just detached enough from the core successful teams that she had to guess Merlin from incomplete signals, which contributed to the mis-assassination. Her read on late-game behavior over-weighted my apparent influence compared to Alice’s quieter guidance.
player_observations.Henry: Came across as very trustworthy once he started appearing on clean missions and then leading the final successful team. His stable, low-drama style made him a comfortable anchor for the endgame good teams.
player_observations.Iris: Joined the successful mid- and late-game teams without generating much controversy, which reinforced her image as a safe inclusion. Her low-key presence helped good by not introducing unnecessary chaos or suspicion when stability was most important.

post_game_reflections.self_assessment: I played cautiously as Mordred and helped secure early mission fails, but I didn't translate that into a convincing Merlin read for the assassin, which ultimately cost us the game. I also blended in a bit too well on the late successful missions, failing to create enough doubt or chaos around Alice and Charlie when it mattered.

player_observations.Alice: Very quiet but precise—her early involvement in a failed team without drawing heat shows she’s good at looking naturally uncertain while subtly steering outcomes as Merlin.
player_observations.Bob: Played a steady, low-drama good role, staying on most teams and building trust by consistently being on successful missions without over-asserting reads.
player_observations.Charlie: Took on a central, vocal role consistent with Percival, defending and shaping team choices in a way that made them look like a potential Merlin decoy.
player_observations.Diana: As Morgana, she did a solid job contributing to early suspicion and a fail, but later didn’t manage to maintain enough pressure on the real Merlin candidates.
player_observations.Eve: Came across as very reasonable and mission-focused; her presence on the last three successful missions without controversy made her a believable Merlin candidate.
player_observations.Grace: As Assassin, she seemed to rely heavily on social reads and visible mission patterns; the final shot on Eve suggests she weighted late mission trust more than early-game subtlety.
player_observations.Henry: Played like a cautious, logical good player—joining successful teams repeatedly and not pushing extreme theories, which helped him stay trusted.
player_observations.Iris: Adopted a fairly low-profile good style, especially late, which kept her from being a major suspicion focus and let her slide onto the final winning team without much resistance.

post_game_reflections.self_assessment: I helped establish early evil credibility by being on and failing the first mission without immediately drawing heavy suspicion, but I didn’t track the information flow well enough to narrow down Merlin by the endgame. I tunneled too hard on Eve based on her mid-game confidence and overlooked how subtly Alice was steering without over-participating in the big logic explanations.

player_observations.Alice: Very controlled and understated; she nudged team compositions just enough to look reasonable without ever being the loudest voice, which made her Merlin game hard to spot in the moment.
player_observations.Bob: Played like a classic cautious good: willing to be on multiple key teams but not aggressively driving discussion, which made him seem reliably safe and a good anchor for later missions.
player_observations.Charlie: As Percival, he leaned into being vocal and analytical, often presenting structured reasoning that gave cover to Merlin while still occasionally including a misdirect or two to protect them.
player_observations.Diana: As Morgana, she did solid work mimicking Merlin-like confidence early, but after the second failed mission her reads started looking a bit too sharp, which probably increased suspicion on her side of the table.
player_observations.Eve: Came across as confidently good but not omniscient—she argued for sensible teams without over-claiming information, which made her look like a very plausible Merlin decoy and pulled my final shot.
player_observations.Frank: Played a low-key Mordred, using his evil perspective mainly to blend into majority opinions rather than lead; his quiet reliability on the later successful teams helped our side look less obviously concentrated.
player_observations.Henry: Adopted a straightforward, logical style, asking the right questions and favoring consistency over flashy deductions, which made him look like a solid good but not quite central enough to be Merlin.
player_observations.Iris: Generally followed group consensus and didn’t push many original theories, which helped her stay in the ‘likely good but not information-rich’ bucket and made her a comfortable inclusion on late missions.

post_game_reflections.self_assessment: I stayed consistently on good-leaning teams and helped lock in a strong core after Mission 2, which contributed to the clean runs on Missions 3–5. I could have been more vocal in challenging the early trust in Charlie and in pressing harder on the Diana/Frank/Grace triangle after the two early fails, to shorten evil’s window of influence.

player_observations.Alice: Played a very low-key Merlin, letting the evidence from missions speak instead of hard-pushing reads, which helped her avoid the assassin’s attention. She subtly nudged teams away from the worst combinations without overcommitting.
player_observations.Bob: Came across as very consistently villagey, especially by being willing to go on multiple later teams without generating extra suspicion. His presence on the triple-success chain (Missions 3–5) reinforced him as a cornerstone of the good bloc.
player_observations.Charlie: As Percival, he looked somewhat suspicious early because of Mission 1’s fail and his proximity to evil, but he managed not to over-clear the wrong people. His midgame behavior made him a natural part of the good core once more information emerged.
player_observations.Diana: Did a strong job as Morgana early, especially by getting onto a failing Mission 2 team in a way that didn’t make her instantly obvious afterward. She projected a reasonably trustworthy tone that forced good to spend time untangling her alignment.
player_observations.Eve: Played a very solid, calm good game, and her presence on the clean missions helped anchor trust in the final team compositions. She attracted the assassination shot, which means her table image was convincingly ‘important good’ without being too obviously non-Merlin.
player_observations.Frank: As Mordred, he leveraged hidden information well by blending into team discussions and not being an obvious source of the early fails. Once the clean team pattern emerged, however, he couldn’t reinsert himself without drawing suspicion.
player_observations.Grace: As Assassin, she created early chaos with the Mission 1 fail while not becoming the primary focus of suspicion afterward. Her final shot on Eve showed she read the good core reasonably well but slightly misjudged who was quietly steering information.

post_game_reflections.self_assessment: I stayed reasonably consistent with a good-table image and didn’t attract suspicion as Merlin, which helped keep heat off the real Merlin late game. I could improve by being more vocal in the early missions about structured reasoning and vote patterns, instead of mostly following others’ logic, especially after the first two failed missions.

player_observations.Alice: Played a very low-key, understated Merlin game—her reads were subtly embedded in team preferences and votes rather than bold pushes, which kept suspicion off her even after the assassin shot elsewhere.
player_observations.Bob: Maintained a very stable, good-lean presence and repeatedly ended up on successful teams, which built trust; he seemed to rely more on consistency and table image than explicit deduction.
player_observations.Charlie: As Percival, he projected strong, confident reads and tried to shape team compositions aggressively, which made him look like a power role without overexposing Merlin.
player_observations.Diana: As Morgana, she leaned into early mission involvement and tried to look like a confident information role, especially around Mission 2, but the single-fail pattern made her positioning increasingly awkward.
player_observations.Eve: Came across as logical and steady, which made her a natural target for the assassin; her presence on multiple successful missions reinforced a ‘likely Merlin or strong good’ image.
player_observations.Frank: As Mordred, he managed to get onto both a failed and a successful mission, blending into the mid-table and not over-pushing, which kept him from being the prime suspect later on.
player_observations.Grace: As the assassin, she seemed to focus heavily on loud/central voices and late-game team influence, which led her to prioritize Eve over quieter but accurate players like Alice.
player_observations.Henry: Played a very clean, trustworthy good game—his late leadership on Missions 4 and 5 felt grounded in accumulated evidence, and he built consensus rather than forcing teams through.
